qas.question: For what type of goods are IP's ethical problems most pertinent?
What is an example of socially valuable goods?
What cost does IP rights allow companies to charge higher than?
Who might a higher price exclude from the market?

answers.text: anyone who cannot afford the cost of the product

plausible_answers.text: higher than the marginal cost of production

qas.question: What do IP rights keep companies from charging?
What does an IRP driven regime encourage production of four poor populations?
What type of goods are exempt from the ethical problems brought on by IP rights?

plausible_answers.text: the costs of research and development

qas.question: What do IP rights keep companies from recouping?

context: Further along these lines, The ethical problems brought up by IP rights are most pertinent when it is <a0_0><b6_0>socially valuable<a0_0/> goods<b6_0/> like <a1_0>life-saving medicines<a1_0/> are given IP protection. While the application of IP rights can allow companies to charge <b4_0>higher than <a2_0>the marginal cost of production<b4_0/><a2_0/> in order to recoup <b7_0>the costs of research and development<b7_0/>, the price may exclude from the market <a3_0>anyone who cannot afford the cost of the product<a3_0/>, in this case a life-saving drug. "An IPR driven regime is therefore not a regime that is conductive to the investment of R&D of <b5_0>products that are socially valuable<b5_0/> to predominately poor populations".:1108–9
